column4: helix: it's an uptime-related timestamp. You can filter it away with sed or awk.
the uptime-relation is obvious. but i'm looking for a way to deactivate it
it eats up space on my screen...
i'm *not* looking for a method to filter them out on a running system. i don't want to have them at boot-time...
i want to see the messages, not the splash-screen. and the timestamp-stuff is annoying (and useless for me)
I don't think there is a kernel option. You can always modify the kernel source, of course
vanilla doesn't display them, but ubuntu does. so they won't come out from nirvana...
how is that sentence logically connected to what I said?
i asked if this is a ubuntu patch, since this makes searching the sources easier
and the standard-sources from kernel.org dont have the timestamps
this is the first time you're asking that
19:52 < he1ix> soundray: is this a ubuntu-applied kernel-patch?
I take it back and apologize
anyways... there seems to be no obvious way to deactivate it. i'll fetch the sources and look there...
